051---Weekly/index.title: 051 - Weekly
051---Weekly/index.content:
If üå¥ Jungle is an experiment in itself, then Weekly is an experiment inside another experiment. An experiment inception!
I‚Äôm a big fan of the Obsidian‚Äôs Daily notes plugin and the Periodic Notes plugin, which is Daily notes on steroids. I‚Äôm using Dailies as a notepad for anything that might come during the day and to give it a small hope of being reused some day in the future. Dailies are private and very unstructured.
The plan for the Weekly notes is to make them like Dailies, but with more thought and effort. Basically I curate everything that I collect in my Dailies and put good enough stuff in the Weekly note. As such, I‚Äôm declaring Weekly notes worthy of being published.

700---Recipies/001---Cinnamon-rolls.title: 001 - Cinnamon rolls
700---Recipies/001---Cinnamon-rolls.content:
Meta

[difficulty:: medium]
[time:: 2h]

Ingredients

2 cups of flour
¬Ω cup of warm milk
1 egg
25g of fresh yeast (or 8g of dry yeast)
55g melted butter
2 flat tablespoons of sugar
a pinch of salt

Additionally

30g of melted butter
2‚Äì3 tablespoons of sugar
2‚Äì3 teaspoons of cinnamon
1 egg for paining the rolls

Preparation
In a small pot put yeast, milk, and sugar; gently warm them on a stove.
To a large bowl add sifted flour, beaten egg, and salt. Mix them together.
Add the yeast mixture to the bowl with flour and work the dough. After a quick mix, add the melted butter and work, until the dough absorbs the butter.
Once the dough is ready, leave it for 40‚Äì50 minutes in a warm place. Cover it with a dry cloth.
Forming rolls
Put the dough on a countertop and work it for a moment to remove any gas that might‚Äôve gathered. Roll out the dough into a rectangle, paint it with the melted butter, sprinkle with sugar and cinnamon. Roll into a roll and cut it into smaller pieces (width around 1.5cm‚Äì2cm).
Lay them on a tray with baking paper and leave them for 20‚Äì30 minutes in a warm place.
Next, turn on the oven to 180¬∞C. Paint the rolls with a beaten egg and bake them for 15‚Äì20 minutes.

700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/001---Y.title: 001 - Yellow pea soup
700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/001---Y.content:
Ingredients

1 small onion
1 small carrot
1 clove of garlic
2 pcs of celery
4 cups vegetable broth
1 ¬º cup yellow peas
1 tsp dried oregano
¬Ω tsp dried thyme
Salt and pepper

Preparation

Finely chop the onion and celery, slice the garlic, and dice the carrots.
Put all ingredients into the rice cooker pot and mix thoroughly.
Close the lid, select the SOUP program and cook for 2 hours.

TIP: Add a tablespoon of cream to the soup and blend with a stick blender.

700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/002---V.title: 002 - Vegetable Thai curry
700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/002---V.content:
Ingredients

1 small onion
1 medium carrot
1 red pepper
230 g broccoli
130 g peas
3 tbsp Thai red or yellow curry paste
200 ml coconut milk
100 ml water
1 tbsp brown sugar
1 tbsp fish sauce

Preparation

Finely chop the onion, peel and dice the carrots, cut the pepper into strips and place in the rice cooker pot along with the peas, curry paste, water and sugar.
Close the lid, select the SLOW COOK program and cook for 45 minutes.
10 minutes before the end of the cooking time, add the broccoli florets, coconut milk, and fish sauce to the pot. Close the lid again and let the program finish.
Stir thoroughly before serving.

TIP: As a side, serve with sticky rice or white bread.

700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/003---S.title: 003 - Spanish chicken with rice
700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/003---S.content:
Ingredients

500 g chicken cutlets
1 onion
3 garlic clovers
1 ¬Ω cups rice
2 cups chicken broth
400g chopped tomatoes (sterilised)
1 tbsp butter
1 tsp ground cumin
2 tbsp chopped parsley
Salt and pepper

Preparation

Finely chop the onion, chop the garlic and put them in the rice cooker pot. Add the rinsed rice, broth, butter, cumin, salt and pepper, and stir thoroughly.
Pour in the tomatoes and add the chicken (cut into large strips) on top. Do not stir.
Close the lid, select the QUICK COOK program and cook for 35 minutes.
Stir again before serving.

TIP: Serve sprinkled with freshly chopped parsley.

700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/004---H.title: 004 - Hong Kong clay pot rice
700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/004---H.content:
Ingredients

1 ¬Ω cups jasmine or basmati rice
Smoked pork belly (approx. 3 cm wide)
1-2 sausages (to taste)
2 ¬Ω cups water
2 tbsp soy sauce
1 tbsp fish sauce
¬Ω tsp sugar
¬Ω tsp white pepper
5 sage leaves

Preparation

Put the rinsed rice, the whole piece of pork belly, sausages, sage, and water in the rice cooker pot.
Close the lid, select the CLAYPOT RICE program and start it.
When the rice is ready, (in about 30 minutes) take out the pork and sausages, and cut them into slices.
Mix the soy sauce, fish sauce, and all other spices together. Add this to the pot along with the meat.
Close the lid and let the program finish.

TIP: Serve in bowls drizzled with soy sauce and add freshly chopped corriander.

700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/005---O.title: 005 - Oatmeal porridge with apples and cinnamon
700---Recipies/001---Rice-cooker/005---O.content:
Ingredients

1 apple
1 cup oatmeal
¬Ω inch cinnamon
1 tbsp brown sugar or honey
1 ¬æ cups water
a pinch of salt

Preparation

Place the diced apple, oats, super, cinnamon, ad pinch of salt, and water in the rice cooker pot.
Close the lid, select the PORRIDGE program and cook until the desired consistency has been reached (approx. 10-15 minutes).
This program can also be stopped manually. It is not necessary to wait till the end of the set time.

TIP: Serve with fresh raspberries or other delicious fruits.

700---Recipies/002---Sushi-rice.title: 002 - Sushi rice
700---Recipies/002---Sushi-rice.content:
Meta

[difficulty:: easy]
[time:: 15min + time for rice cooker to finish cooking]

Ingredients

Sushi rice
Rice vinegar
Sugar
Salt

Preparation
Wash the rise in a bowl of cold tap water multiple times, until the water no longer changes color. Allow it to dry for 5 minutes.
Put the rice in the rice cooker; add the same amount of water by volume. Turn on the cooking.
Pour 20% of dry rice volume of vinegar to a bowl. Add 10% of dry rice volume of sugar (or ¬Ω of the vinegar volume) to the same bowl. Add 2.5% of dry rice volume of salt (or ¬º of the sugar volume) to the same bowl. Stir until fully dissolved.
When the rice is ready, transport it to a large bowl and add the vinegar mixture. Gently stir the rice, so that each grain gets covered in the vinegar mixture.
As the last step, gently spread the rice using a 45¬∞ cutting motion to break up any lumps and to separate the rice.
Sushi rice is ready to be used.

Links.title: Links
Links.content:
Ens≈ç ‚Äî a writing tool that helps you enter a state of flow.
mess with dns ‚Äî perform DNS experiments without consequences.
HackerNews blogs newsletter ‚Äî a substack blog aggregating on a daily basis blog entries submitted to HN.
DevDocs ‚Äî combines multiple API documentations in a fast, organized, and searchable interface.
The Punctuation Guide ‚Äî The web‚Äôs most comprehensive guide to American punctuation. 
Goodreads HTML formatting ‚Äî Goodreads supports a set list of html tags that you can use to format your comments, reviews, and stories & writing.
A List of Hacker News‚Äôs Undocumented Features and Behaviors
Excalidraw ‚Äî a virtual collaborative whiteboard tool that lets you easily sketch diagrams that have a hand-drawn feel to them.
LessWrong ‚Äî is an online forum and community dedicated to improving human reasoning and decision-making. We seek to hold true beliefs and to be effective at accomplishing our goals. Each day, we aim to be less wrong about the world than the day before.
Obsidian Roadmap ‚Äî list of futureObsidian features.

index.title: üå¥ Jungle
index.content:
Welcome to the üå¥ Jungle!
What is this?
I‚Äôve been using Obsidian for some time already and I found it to be a great place for storing information in a loosely-manner, so it can be retrieved at a later time. I was thinking about publishing my notes for some time, but I wanted to do so in a more controlled way.
Also, I‚Äôve been toying with an idea to add recipes and short notes sections to my website. Frankly, I lacked the motivation to create new subpage templates with the necessary functionality.
Meet üå¥ Jungle!
üå¥ Jungle is mostly an experiment; it‚Äôs a digital garden of sorts. I‚Äôm planning to publish some of my Obsidian notes here, so that they can be easily accessed by me and my friends, on any device.
Why not publish on madebyme.today
I‚Äôve established an unwritten contact between me and my readers ‚Äî madebyme.today is for tech-related articles. I feel like if I‚Äôd publish a TTRPG session log or a cinnamon roll recipe on my website, I‚Äôd break that contract.
Think of it like this:

madebyme.today is only for tech,
üå¥ Jungle is not only for tech ‚Äî it is more Kamil.

What can I find here?
Who knows? ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø
The notes are kind of unstructured ‚Äî I‚Äôll put here anything I‚Äôm willing to share with the internet ‚Äî and only marginally reviewed before publishing, so you can expect typos and 404s.
Is it published with Obsidian Publish?
No.
Obsidian Publish is a great tool, but it does not allow you to fully customise the static website it produces. For this project I‚Äôve decided to go with Quartz by Jacky. Quartz is a static-site generator ‚Äî like Hugo ‚Äî but it was built with Obsidian in mind; it handles Wikilinks, Callouts, and many other Obsidian features out-of-the-box.
